rsbNotes.title: Jer 37–39
rsbNotes.text: 37:1–39:18 These chapters recount Jeremiah’s last warnings before the fall of Jerusalem and his imprisonment for his unpopular message. His repeated advice to surrender to the Babylonians is ignored, and he remains imprisoned until the fall of Jerusalem.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 39:1
rsbNotes.text: 39:1 tenth month. January, 588 b.c. (52:4; 2 Kin. 25:1).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 39:2
rsbNotes.text: 39:2 ninth day . . . month. That is, July, 586 b.c. (52:5–7; 2 Kin. 25:2–4); the siege had lasted two and a half years.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 39:3
rsbNotes.text: 39:3 sat in the middle gate. This fulfills 1:15. The officials’ names are formed with those of Babylonian gods (Nebo, Nergal).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 39:11–12
rsbNotes.text: 39:11, 12 Nebuchadnezzar . . . gave command concerning Jeremiah. How much of the prophet’s message the king knew is not clear; he probably regarded him as a Babylonian sympathizer (though see 25:12).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 40:5
rsbNotes.text: 40:5 Gedaliah. See 26:24. Gedaliah is receptive to Jeremiah’s understanding of events.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 40:10
rsbNotes.text: 40:10 gather wine and summer fruits and oil. At the moment of judgment, we are given a glimpse of future blessing in the land. Contrast the drought conditions during parts of Jeremiah’s earlier preaching (14:1–6 and notes).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 41:1
rsbNotes.text: 41:1 As they ate bread together. This hospitality emphasizes the treachery of Ishmael the son of Nethaniah.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 41:5
rsbNotes.text:
41:5 from Shechem . . . Shiloh . . . Samaria. These cities were important religious centers in the former northern kingdom that fell in 722 b.c. The men are a remnant of Israel’s population who had made pilgrimages to Jerusalem for the great feasts (in accordance with Ex. 23:14–17). The time of year (the “seventh month,” see v. 1) was the Feast of Booths.

with their beards shaved . . . bodies gashed. These actions are signs of mourning for the fall of Jerusalem.

the temple of the Lord. Although the temple had been destroyed, the temple mount was still regarded as holy.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 41:7
rsbNotes.text: 41:7 the city. That is, Mizpah (v. 6).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 41:10
rsbNotes.text:
41:10 the king’s daughters. Members of Zedekiah’s court, not just the king’s own daughters.

Ammonites. Part of the former alliance against Babylon (27:3), the Ammonite action is itself under God’s judgment (27:8; 49:1–6).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 41:11–44:30
rsbNotes.text: 41:11–44:30 Jeremiah is taken to Egypt by Jewish survivors fleeing from possible Babylonian reprisals.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 41:15
rsbNotes.text: 41:15 escaped . . . with eight men. Two men were presumably lost in the skirmish (v. 2).
